data.title: News Archives for Latest
data.meta_description: Latest News on Business, Finance and Markets from Pakistan
data.text:
HEALTH UPDATE: Alzheimer's spreads faster among the highly educated

Having a university education may help ward off the onset of Alzheimer's disease, but it can speed up its progression once the disorder has developed, according to a study published on February 16.

HEALTH UPDATE: computed tomography screening can identify curable lung cancers

Computed tomography (CT) screening identifies many cases of early, curable lung cancer, according to the International Early Lung Cancer Action Program Investigators.

HEALTH UPDATE: eat soyabeans to prevent prostate cancer

Eating food like soyabeans and linseeds that naturally contain estrogen-like compounds helps prevent prostate cancer, a researcher in charge of a new Swedish study on the subject said on February 14.

HEALTH UPDATE: expanding waistline raises women's gallstone risk

An expansion in a woman's waistline increases her risk of suffering from gallstones and needing surgery to remove them, a study published on February 14 showed.

Feuding parents disrupt kids' emotional stability, sleep patterns

Two studies published in the journal Child Development have shown that children suffer from emotional difficulties and lack of sleep even if their parents are involved in a small fight.

HEALTH UPDATE: glaucoma eye pressure higher in sleep

Some patients with glaucoma may have greater pressure in their eyes during sleep, meaning that the severity of the disease can go unrecognised during exams that only involve daytime office visits, a study said on February 13.

Water reservoirs - needs, challenges and solutions

Pakistan will be facing serious challenges in irrigation and energy sectors during years ahead, if new water reservoirs were not built. Over the decades, the thoughts of constructing new reservoirs could not be transformed into acts due to certain reasons

International Children Cancer Day: late diagnosis, lack of specialised units hinder treatment

International Children Cancer Day is celebrated all over the world on 15th February every year. Different cancer awareness programmes have been arranged on this occasion for the lay public to understand the problems and solutions related to the disease es

Greenland's glaciers disappearing more quickly

Greenland's glaciers are dumping more than twice as much ice into the Atlantic Ocean now as 10 years ago because glaciers are sliding off the land more quickly, researchers said on February 16.

Sleep could solve headache problems

If your child is dogged by headaches, he or she might also have another problem: frequent sleep disturbances. Researchers at the Mayo Clinic have found that more than two-thirds of children ages 6 to 17 suffering from chronic headaches also have sleep pro

Pledging continuity, Bernanke breaks with Greenspan

New US central bank chief Ben Bernanke last week used his first congressional appearance to pledge continuity with the Greenspan Fed, but broke with his famous predecessor by refusing to offer fiscal policy advice.

Kingfisher Airlines signs deal

India's private Kingfisher Airlines Sunday signed a deal to purchase 15 ATR 72-500 aircraft for 270 million dollars, with the option to buy another 20.

India tests for H5N1, Cairo shuts zoo as flu spreads

India said it was testing dozens of people for bird flu on Sunday and France confirmed its first avian cases of the H5N1 virus as the deadly strain spread around the globe.

Europe ill-equipped to cope with rust-bucket ships

The fiasco over the French aircraft carrier Clemenceau highlights Europe's lack of facilities for wrecking old ships, according to industrialists and environmentalists. Since the 1970s the rendering of rust-bucket vessels into valuable scrap metal has shi

US faces limited options in trade fight with China

Reminiscent of 1980s Japan-bashing, Washington is revving up criticism of China to rectify a burgeoning trade deficit, but its options are limited and any retaliatory actions could backfire, analysts say.

Mittal confident of clinching Arcelor deal

Lakshmi Mittal, head of the Netherland-based Mittal Steel, says his bid for Luxembourg-based Arcelor is about setting new goals rather than making money, a report said Sunday.

Dubai investing $15 billion into aviation services hub

Dubai launched its maiden voyage into the global aerospace industry on Sunday by investing $15 billion in an aviation services corporation that is eyeing the booming markets of Asia and the Middle East.

Bird flu boom for throwaway mask manufacturers

The demand for throwaway face masks has exploded as deadly bird flu sweeps across the globe, manufacturers say. The world leader in personal protection equipment, Bacou-Dalloz, says its factory in western France is operating 24 hours a day, seven days a w

EU energy groups in Brussels' sights over market 'malfunctions'

The European Commission is raising pressure on energy groups to fire up competition as consumers grow increasingly impatient for the benefits of EU market liberalisation.

Iran approves foreign loans for public transport

Iran's parliament has approved using $4 billion worth of foreign loans in the year to March 2007, primarily to upgrade public transport, the spokesman for parliament's budget committee said on Sunday.

Malaysia eyes 20 million tourist arrivals in 2007

Malaysia is hoping to attract some 20.1 million tourists in 2007, up from 15.7 million in 2004 and hopes to increase revenues by 50 percent, officials were quoted as saying Sunday.

Superior Indian batting line-up undo Pakistan

Pakistan made shoddy work of their efforts to restore battered morale as India crushed them by a debilitating eight wickets in the fifth and final one-day international at the National Stadium here on Sunday.

Jayawardene relishing captaincy challenge in Bangladesh

Sri Lanka's Mahela Jayawardene is relishing his new role as captain in the three-match one-day series in Bangladesh starting on Monday. "We want to win everything we play. So we are here for win with a high confidence," Jayawardene told reporters on Sunda

Viloria retains WBC light flyweight title

American Brian Viloria retained his World Boxing Council light flyweight title here Saturday with a 12-round unanimous decision over Mexico's Jose Antonio Aguirre.

Pakistan drag India from rating table

India's Test series defeat at the hands of neighbours Pakistan has cost them more than just local bragging rights; it has also dropped them down one place in the latest LG ICC Test Championship table.

Inzamam retained as captain

Inzamamul Haq has been retained as Pakistan captain until the end of this year despite his team's one-day series defeat against arch-rivals India, Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) announced Sunday.

Dravid passes 9,000 runs in ODIs

India captain Rahul Dravid became the fourth Indian and eighth batsman to score over 9,000 runs in one-day internationals (ODIs) on Sunday. He achieved the feat in the third over of the Indian innings in the fifth and final one-dayer against Pakistan, dri

Sabbatini leads by four at Nissan Open

South African Rory Sabbatini fired a four-under 67 on Saturday to seize a four-shot lead after three rounds of the 5.1 million-dollar Nissan Open.

Pakistan retain youth World Cup as Ali wrecks India

Fast bowler Anwar Ali grabbed three wickets in his opening over as Pakistan retained the under-19 cricket World Cup with a sensational 38-run win over India in the final here on Sunday.

Pakistan and India reject International Twenty20 Cup

Pakistan and India have rejected the idea of a World Twenty20 Championship as they think it would not gel with the hectic international schedule, officials said here on Sunday.

Murray shocks Roddick to reach San Jose final

Scotland's Andy Murray ended Andy Roddick's bid for a "three-peat" at the 355,000-dollar ATP hardcourt tournament here Saturday. The 18-year-old Murray defeated top seed and world number three Roddick 7-5, 7-5 to book his place in the final, where he'll f

Sheehan wins Open in playoff

Paul Sheehan beat fellow Australian Michael Sim in a playoff to win the South Australian Open at Royal Adelaide on Sunday. Sheehan won with a bogey-five on the second extra hole after Sim hit his tee shot out of bounds and finished with a six.

KKI weekly review

Khanani & Kalia International (Pvt) Limited weekly review of currency notes on Sunday (February 19, 2006).

Textile Spinning: NAGINA COTTON MILLS LIMITED - Period (9 Months) Ended June 30, 2005

This large textile spinning unit of Industrial Trading Estate, Kotri Sindh has registered very high gross profit margin and net profit after taxation. The performance is for nine months only but even then compared to last year's corresponding figure of 12

This large textile spinning unit of Industrial Trading Estate, Kotri Sindh has registered very high gross profit margin and net profit after taxation. The performance is for nine months only but even then compared to last year's corresponding figure of 12

Your rupee last week

Following currency fluctuations took place in foreign exchange rates during the last week. (February 13 to 18, 2006).

Mutual Funds Association has issued open-end funds daily prices on February 20, 2006.

The weather report on Sunday (February 19, 2006) and the forecast for Monday (February 20, 2006).

Cartoon protesters teargassed in Islamabad

Police fired teargas and rubber bullets to disperse hundreds of demonstrators in the federal capital on Sunday, despite sealing the city to stop MMA activists protesting against blasphemous cartoons published in Denmark and some other European countries.

Cartoon protesters teargassed in Islamabad

Police fired teargas and rubber bullets to disperse hundreds of demonstrators in the federal capital on Sunday, despite sealing the city to stop MMA activists protesting against blasphemous cartoons published in Denmark and some other European countries.

Qazi restrained

The police on Sunday barred MMA Chief Qazi Hussian from going out of Mansoora, the Jamat-i-Islami headquarters, to lead a procession to join a rally in the federal capital against the blasphemous caricatures.

Qazi restrained

The police on Sunday barred MMA Chief Qazi Hussian from going out of Mansoora, the Jamat-i-Islami headquarters, to lead a procession to join a rally in the federal capital against the blasphemous caricatures.

PTCL deal likely by Friday: Etisalat team in Islamabad

A seven-member Etisalat Telecom team has arrived in Islamabad to finalise the deal with the Privatisation Commission for Pakistan Telecom Company Limited (PTCL), it is learnt.

PTCL deal likely by Friday: Etisalat team in Islamabad

A seven-member Etisalat Telecom team has arrived in Islamabad to finalise the deal with the Privatisation Commission for Pakistan Telecom Company Limited (PTCL), it is learnt.

PTCL deal likely by Friday: Etisalat team in Islamabad

A seven-member Etisalat Telecom team has arrived in Islamabad to finalise the deal with the Privatisation Commission for Pakistan Telecom Company Limited (PTCL), it is learnt.

Musharraf arrives in Beijing

President Pervez Musharraf arrived in Beijing on Sunday for a state visit intended to highlight China's support at a time when Pakistan faces domestic and regional uncertainty.

Musharraf arrives in Beijing

President Pervez Musharraf arrived in Beijing on Sunday for a state visit intended to highlight China's support at a time when Pakistan faces domestic and regional uncertainty.

11 killed in Iraq bombings, shootings

A spate of bombings and shootings on Sunday across Iraq claimed the lives of 11 people, including an Iraqi police general, security officials said. Three Iraqis died and eight were wounded in two separate bombings within minutes of each other nearby Baghd

THE RUPEE: dollar improves on higher demand

Rising demand for dollars in the local market and persistent its firmness in the world markets, kept the rupee under pressure slightly last week, money experts said.

THE RUPEE: dollar improves on higher demand

Rising demand for dollars in the local market and persistent its firmness in the world markets, kept the rupee under pressure slightly last week, money experts said.

Muslims deeply hurt by cartoons: chief minister

Punjab Chief Minister Chaudhry Pervaiz Elahi in a meeting with Town Nazims and Union Council Nazims here on Sunday said that Muslim throughout the world had deeply been hurt by publication of blasphemous material against Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

Punjab Assembly

Punjab Assembly is expected to hold its session on February 24. A proper notification in this connection is yet to be issued. This would be 24th session of Punjab Assembly.

Half-year growth rate estimated at 6.4 percent

The country's growth rate has been estimated at 6.4 percent, against 7 percent target of first six months (July-December) of current fiscal, which is mainly attributed to low agriculture output, whereas manufacturing sector data paints a different picture

Half-year growth rate estimated at 6.4 percent

The country's growth rate has been estimated at 6.4 percent, against 7 percent target of first six months (July-December) of current fiscal, which is mainly attributed to low agriculture output, whereas manufacturing sector data paints a different picture

Thar Express completes maiden roundtrip

The first, and a historic, return trip of Thar Express successfully completed as the new train carrying 260 Indian passengers reached Karachi Cantonment station on Sunday from Indian border town of Munabao.

KSE maintains winning streak

The share market last week maintained its winning streak for the 14th consecutive week since November 2005 while market capitalisation peaked at $54 billion as buying spree from financial institutions and overseas fund managers trickled into the local bou

Open interest climbs to Rs 18.8 billion

Open interest at February futures counter increased by around Rs 1.2 billion to reach Rs 18.8 billion, against Rs 17.6 billion of last week, as the prices rose sharply during the week. The value of open interest was at its highest level since March 2005.

Open interest climbs to Rs 18.8 billion

Open interest at February futures counter increased by around Rs 1.2 billion to reach Rs 18.8 billion, against Rs 17.6 billion of last week, as the prices rose sharply during the week. The value of open interest was at its highest level since March 2005.

Abdali missile test-fired

Pakistan successfully test-fired on Sunday the indigenously developed short-range surface-to-surface ballistic missile Hataf-II 'Abdali'. The Abdali SSM can reach targets up to 200 km and can carry nuclear and other types of warheads. All planned technica

Banks' results likely to cheer up moods

Investors would see a number of financial results this week, especially from the banking group, such as United Bank, Askari and Faysal, where analysts forecast significant growth in net earnings of these institutions.

Banks' results likely to cheer up moods

Investors would see a number of financial results this week, especially from the banking group, such as United Bank, Askari and Faysal, where analysts forecast significant growth in net earnings of these institutions.

Seven explosions rock Loti, Pir Koh gas fields

Seven explosions rocked Loti and Pir Koh gas fields on Saturday-Sunday night. According to details, unknown terrorists blew up gas pipelines and damaged gas wells in Loti and Pir Koh gas fields on Saturday-Sunday night. Six explosions were heard in Loti a

Seven explosions rock Loti, Pir Koh gas fields

LSE index gains 4.20 percent

The local share market gained 4.20 percent during the last week, ended Friday, 17th February, though mostly it moved roller coaster on account of corrections, which are a useful phenomenon and considered healthy for the equity market.

LSE index gains 4.20 percent

The local share market gained 4.20 percent during the last week, ended Friday, 17th February, though mostly it moved roller coaster on account of corrections, which are a useful phenomenon and considered healthy for the equity market.

China power industry sees pressure easing

China will face power shortages again this year but much less than previously, an industry association official said in remarks published in the People's Daily on Sunday.

South Korea to cut financial sector restrictions

South Korea will scrap some restrictions in the financial sector through a new law that will allow companies to offer stock brokerage, futures trading and asset management under one roof, the finance ministry said.

MONEY WEEK: rise in private sector credit, NFA push up money supply

British Parliamentarians arrive

A four-member delegation of the British Parliament has arrived in Islamabad on a four-day visit on Sunday. According to a press release issued here the delegation has arrived at the invitation of Special Committee of the Parliament on Kashmir.

British Parliamentarians arrive

A four-member delegation of the British Parliament has arrived in Islamabad on a four-day visit on Sunday. According to a press release issued here the delegation has arrived at the invitation of Special Committee of the Parliament on Kashmir.

Southern Punjab health facilities reviewed

Timely completion of work urged

Punjab Mineral Development Minister Muhammad Sibtain Khan while addressing a meeting here on Sunday has asked the concerned departments to complete development work in areas where mineral wealth was available. He gave a deadline of June 30, 2006 for compl

Permission granted for institute

Punjab Chief Minister Chaudhry Pervaiz Elahi has given permission to establish Pir Qatal Institute of Science and Technology. This was stated by Punjab Agricultural Marketing Minister Rana Qasim Noon in a meeting with a farmer delegation here on Sunday. T

Population control urged

Minister for Population Welfare Punjab Naseem Lodhi meeting a delegation of Women here on Sunday told that with the establishment of Mobile Service Units, special teams of paramedical staff are being made for enhancing pace of population control measures

Bahraini team due today

A four-member delegation of the Kingdom of Bahrain headed by Minister of Social Development Dr Fatima Muhammad Al-Balooshi will arrive here, on Monday. The delegation will meet Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz and Punjab Chief Minister Chaudhry Pervaiz Elahi a

Muslims hurt by publication of sketches: Shaukat

Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz has said the Government and Pakistan Muslim League have condemned the publishing of sacrilegious caricatures in some western newspapers at all forums world-wide.

Quake zone projects: $2.6 billion loans firmly committed: foreign office

Negotiations for over $2.3 billion in loans have been completed and the amount has been firmly committed against specific projects, while an agreement for $300 million for reconstruction in the earthquake-hit areas is expected to be signed during the Pres

Churches attacked in Sukkur: desecration of Quran alleged

Hundreds of protestors attacked two churches in Sukkur on Sunday after allegations that a Christian teenager had desecrated the Quran, a government official said, adding that no one was hurt.

Situation back to normal in Hangu: minister

Minister for Tourism, Dr Ghazi Ghulab Jamal said life was back to normal in Hangu and surrounding areas owing to tireless efforts of Provincial and Federal governments. The minister in meeting with Jirga which included member from Sunni and Shia communiti

'Muslim countries should adopt merit in all sectors'

"Muslim countries should adopt merit and competition in all sectors to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs)," was the consensus among the speakers at a seminar here on Sunday.

Water pollution in twin cities alarmingly high

Millions of twin-city residents are exposed to certain health hazards, as they have to drink contaminated water. Different studies manifest that water pollution level in the twin cities is alarmingly high and there's no mechanism in place to control it.

Trade via Pakistan to benefit people: Jadoon

Minister for Petroleum and Natural Resources, Amanullah Khan Jadoon said Pakistan would not be the only beneficiary of trade of energy and other goods through its territory, rather it would benefit one billion people of the sub-continent.

Danish envoy returns

Denmark has ordered its ambassador in Pakistan to return home following the closure of the country's embassy in Islamabad, the foreign ministry said on Sunday.

Rally held against blasphemous sketches

Anjuman Tajiran Balochistan organised a rally here on Sunday in collaboration with Peace Committee against the publication of blasphemous sketches in some European newspapers.

Josh's death anniversary on February 22

The death anniversary of the noted poet Josh Malihabadi would be observed under the auspices of the Josh Foundation Daira in collaboration with the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTCL) here on February 22.

Comstech moot on February 21

The twelfth meeting of the General Assembly of OIC's Ministerial Standing Committee on Science and Technological Co-operation (Comstech) has been convened in Islamabad from February 21 to 23.

Directive to follow Pakistan Flag Rules

The Interior Ministry has asked all the ministries, divisions, public and private sector to follow Pakistan Flag Rules in letter and spirit, said a ministry spokesman.

Telecom users may face interruption

The people using telecom network may face some interruption during 0200 to 0300 hours on Tuesday (February 21), due to upgradation work to be carried out in some areas of the federal capital. The phones starting with the prefixes 220, 227, 265, 269, 282,

Shujaat names body for party polls

President Pakistan Muslim League Chaudhry Shujaat Hussain on Sunday appointed an Election Coordination Committee (ECC) to ensure free, fair and transparent party elections at all tiers by August 14.

Kashmir issue nearer to solution: Sikandar

Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Prime Minister Sardar Sikandar Hayat Khan on Sunday declared that Kashmir issue is nearer to its peaceful solution in the near future.

Modern knowledge vital: Soomro

Chairman Senate and Acting President Muhammadmian Soomro has urged the Muslim World especially African countries to acquire modern knowledge to keep pace with development process in the current scenario.

SAEF condemns caricatures

Syed Faseih Iqbal, President of South Asian Editors Forum (SAEF) and ex-senator has condemned the publication of blasphemous sketches in some Western media.

CDA to build 2 more underpasses

The Capital Development Authority (CDA) has started homework for establishing two more underpasses in the capital. It is learnt that consulting firm has been directed to prepare a design of underpasses at Shaheed-e-Millat Secretariat Chowk and Faisal Aven

Ginners gain price-dictating position

The spinners disappointed over government decision not to offer cotton to mills returned to market giving boost to ginners courage to stock until consumers realised they were on the wrong foot. Strangely huge buying was noted on higher side such as Rs 257

PAEC, HEC may join hands for wasteland project

The Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission (PAEC) and Higher Education Commission (HEC), are likely to work on a joint project to bring vast areas of salinity-hit wasteland into productive use.

Prices fluctuate due to supply constraints

Sharp upturn was noted on the wholesale commodity markets during the week ended on February 18, 2006, owing mainly to tight supply position caused by rally and protest against blasphemous cartoons printed in European countries.

Fair weather forecast

The Met Office has forecast fair/partly cloudy weather for Karachi on Monday with maximum temperature in range of 20 and 22 degree Centigrade.

'Extremism hurting socioeconomic efforts'

NWFP Governor Khalil-ur-Rehman has said the prevailing trends of extremism in the society are not only regrettable but also may cause to bring negative effects on the socioeconomic efforts in the country as well.

Arbab inquires about Pagara's health

Sindh Chief Minister Dr Arbab Ghulam Rahim visited Aga Khan Hospital to inquire about the health of spiritual Leader of Hur community and senior leader of Muslim League (Functional) Pir Sahab Pagara here, on Sunday.

IBP to pay tributes to legendary bankers today

As part of its knowledge week, an initiative to energise creative intellect, the Institute of Bankers Pakistan is organising a special evening programme dedicated to pay tributes to the luminaries of the banking history of Pakistan.

Jam meets Arbab

Balochistan Chief Minister, Jam Muhammad Yousuf called on Sindh Chief Minister Dr Arbab Ghulam Rahim at Chief Minister's House here on Sunday and exchanged views on matters of mutual interests.

I I Chundrigar Road will be closed for all public transport from Monday while shuttle service is being started from Saddar to Tower via I I Chundrigar Road to facilitate users of public transport.

Railways to launch new train service

Pakistan Railways has decided to launch new train service from Rawalpindi to Havelian on unremitting demand of masses. The train will start its journey at 6.30 am from Rawalpindi and arrive in Havelian at 9.05 am.

Jamaat-i-Islami calls for enforcement of Shariah

Need stressed to institutionalise training for disabled

Corps Commander Karachi, Lieutenant General Ather Ali has underlined the need for institutionalising the training process for disabled and handicapped persons to help them become self-confident and active members of the society.

SCA concerned over 'covert construction' of KBD

The Sindh Chamber of Agriculture (SCA) has expressed grave concern over what it called "continuation of construction work of Kalabagh dam secretly," and demanded from President, Prime Minister and Sindh Chief Minister to stop the same.

Protestors block National Highway

'China and Pakistan share similar position on counter-terrorism'

Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing said on Sunday that Pakistan and China share similar and common position on counter-terrorism and enjoy full co-operation in all fields of common interests.

Federal Tax Ombudsman decides 7354 complaints

The office of Federal Tax Ombudsman received a total of 7668 complaints since its establishment and decided 7354 cases with 85 percent implementation ratio.

Bomb blast at judge's residence

Residence of an Additional Session Judge Tandlianwala, Javed Iqbal Ranjha was badly damaged when a bomb planted in his home exploded violently on Saturday evening at Tandlianwala some 200 kms north east of Multan.

Through this letter, I would like to draw the attention of the PCB to the pathetic lack of maintenance at the National Stadium, which I had visited to watch the 4th day of the Test match.

Bhasha dam to bring prosperity: NALC

Speaker, Northern Areas Legislative Council, Malik Mohammad Miskeen on Sunday said the construction of Bhasha dam would bring prosperity and economic revolution in the area.

Anti-polio campaigns showing results

The Government's aggressive nation-wide mass vaccination campaigns against the crippling disease of polio have brought the country closer to achieve polio-free status, with only 17 cases of the disease reported during 2005.

Tax Bar Association opposes Bush visit

Tax Bar Association in its meeting on Sunday demanded for cancellation of visit of US President George Bush and asked the Muslim states to use the oil as weapon and boycott the products of Denmark and European countries.

Ahmedabad on high alert after 25 hurt in bomb blast

India's western Ahmedabad city was placed on high alert Sunday after 25 people were injured, three of them seriously, in a bomb blast at the main railway station, police said.
